column4: I have disk image. i want to mount it everytime I log in. how can I do that?  The user has no root-right on that account?
would 'every time you boot up' be sufficient ?
disk image ,being  something you are mounting  with   -o loop   etc. ?
On every boot its sufficient. It should only be mounted for a special user
how are you mounting it at present?  and what sort of filesystem *is* the image?  then I can explain options...
i wouldn't have thought we can mount it only for a special user as such  BUT  can set the filesystem permissions so only one use can read it,  which depends on the filesystem
yes, but you havent' answered my qusetion ;-)
it can be mounted on boot, and the filesystem permissions can be set so that other users can't go into that subdirectory.  What sort of filesystem is in the disk images?
i.e. is it  an ISO9660, ext4,  FAT32, ntfs, etc. ?
are you mounting using  -o loop,offset=????  to mount each partition?
It has ext3 ext4, ntfs and a 100m dos partition
right.  now you say you don't want other users to be able to access the contents of any of his mounts?
ok then you can just add entries in /etc/fstab to mount them there...  the various columns will allow you to add the needed options
yes don't worry about that =)  its not like windows running out of drive letters
btw i was gong to explain , if somebodys directory is traversible, then you can use  -o uid -o gid -o mode  etc.  to set the apparent permissions on  DOS fat portitions mounted
